Award.AwardTitle: MARGINS: Collaborative Research: Illuminating the Architecture of the Greater Mount St. Helens Magmatic System from Slab to Surface
Award.AbstractNarration:
To better understand volcanic activity, it is fundamental to get an accurate representation of magma generation zones and storage regions in the Earth?s crust and upper mantle. Illuminating the architecture of the plumbing system beneath volcanoes will allow scientists to determine (1) at which depths and conditions magmas are generated, and (2) the shapes and sizes of pathways and reservoirs along which magma travels towards the surface. Such knowledge will allow scientists to make more informed predictions on the durations of volcanic crises and on the total volume of erupted material during eruptive episodes.

This project focuses on the Mount St. Helens volcanic edifice, (WA, USA), whose explosive eruption in 1980 attracted world?s attention, and was the first volcano to be thoroughly monitored with modern instruments. Mount St. Helens provides an ideal setting to apply state-of-the-art geophysical and geochemical techniques to image its subterranean roots: It is active, easily accessible, and has a well recorded past history. The project will use several different methods (active and passive source seismic tomography and scattered wave imaging, magnetotelluric imaging, petrology and geochemistry), involving a large collaborative team, to image the volcano?s plumbing system with unprecedented resolution from the subducting plate to the surface. The results will be informative for many other volcanoes around the world, particularly those located along the infamous Pacific Ring of Fire.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The imaging Magma Under St. Helens (iMUSH) project aims to image the architecture of the magmatic system beneath the most active volcano in the contiguous U.S using a variety of techniques, including geologic, electromagnetic, and seismologic investigations. At the University of Washington, the primary work was in collecting and analyzing data from a large, passive-source, seismic dataset.

After two years spent looking for ideal seismic site locations, in the summer of 2014 we installed 70 broadband seismometers in a 100-km-aperture array around Mount St. Helens. The primary fieldwork spanned three weeks and involved 15-20 volunteers, including PIs, undergraduate, and graduate students from the University of Washington, the USGS Cascade Volcano Observatory, and Columbia University. These 70 stations recorded 23 buried explosions in July and August, 2014, that were part of the active-source portion of the iMUSH experiment. The broadband stations remained in place for two years, recording local earthquakes and other signals, and required service visits every 4-6 months. In late summer of 2016, the seismometers were removed by a team of 10-15 people. Throughout the deployment, data were downloaded, cleaned and then archived at the IRIS Data Management Center. In total, the return rate on the data was 94% with missing data caused by power issues, flooding, fire and vandalism.

Analysis of the broadband data performed at the University of Washington included a study of deep long-period earthquakes (DLPs) beneath Mount St. Helens by Ph.D. student Jiangang Han, and a study performing local earthquake tomography by Ph.D. student Carl Ulberg. 

The primary results of the DLP study include the detection of 277 DLPs, 274 of which are repeating events at the same location at ~25 km depth, 5 km SE of Mount St. Helens. The DLPs were found to be moderately influenced by compressive tidal stresses. These events are located near a fast-to-slow seismic velocity boundary imaged by the active-source portion of the iMUSH experiment (Kiser et al., 2016), and could possibly indicate fractures or cracks associated with magma or fluids rising within the crust.

The primary observations of the local earthquake tomography study include: (1) Low P- and S-wave velocities along the St. Helens seismic zone to depths of at least 20 km corresponding to high electrical conductivity imaged by iMUSH magnetotelluric studies; (2) A 3-7% negative P- and S-wave cylindrical velocity anomaly beneath MSH at 6-15 km depth and 5-8 km in diameter. We interpret this as a magma storage region containing up to 15-20 km3of partial melt, which is about 5 times more than the largest documented eruption at MSH; (3) A broad, low P-wave velocity region below 10-km depth extending between Mount Adams and Mount Rainier along and to the east of the main Cascade arc, which is likely due to high-temperature arc crust and possible presence of fluids or melt; (4) Several anomalies associated with surface-mapped features, including high-velocity igneous rocks such as the Spud Mountain and Spirit Lake plutons and low velocities in the Chehalis sedimentary basin and the Indian Heaven volcanic field.

Additional analyses performed at the UW include: (1) A study by postdoc Xiaofeng Meng detecting and precisely relocating earthquakes in the upper 5 km beneath Mount St. Helens using a dense array of 900 geophones deployed during the active-source part of the iMUSH experiment. These observations suggest the existence of a highly-fractured shallow hydrothermal area underneath Mount St. Helens; (2) Calculation of the orientation of the broadband seismometers using analysis of surface waves by undergraduate IRIS intern Gina Belair; (3) Relocation of additional earthquakes using the program hypoDD by undergraduate IRIS intern Mitchell Williams; (4) Obtaining accurate, relative, arrival times of distant, teleseismic P-waves using cross-correlation methods by UW undergraduate Luke Fisher; (5) Relocation and comparison to mainshock-aftershock sequence of a cluster of earthquakes beneath Spirit Lake, WA, to the NE of Mount St. Helens by UW undergraduate and then master?s student Nancy Sackman.

In summary, we have increased our understanding of the magmatic pathways and tectonic setting of Mount St. Helens. The grant helped support 2 undergraduates, 1 masters, 2 PhDs, and 1 postdoc. We have worked in collaboration with other members of the iMUSH project, from Rice University, Oregon State University, Cornell University, the University of New Mexico, the University of Arizona, the US Geological Survey, and the ETH, Zurich. We acquired a substantial broadband data set that is archived and freely available at the IRIS DMC. We have published 7 peer-reviewed papers, and have given over 20 presentations at international conferences. A Scientific American article was written about this experiment and its results.
